Members of the House and the Senate today asked citizens for ideas on how to improve the No Child Left Behind education law, and they got an earful.
The law is up for re-authorization this year.
As NPR's Larry Abramson reports, Congress is focusing on how to improve teacher quality.
Lawmakers are still in the information-gathering phase on how to improve the five-year-old education law.
Former Georgia Governor Roy Barnes recommended that members of the House Senate hearing get started by taking a peek at a recent report by his No Child Left Behind commission.
Our report contains specific and actionable recommendations, about 75.
Whoa, 75 recommendations to a law that has already generated thousands of pages of regulations.
You could almost hear the collective oi vey in the room.
Other witnesses kept their list more reasonable.
One had eight, another proffered 14, but then during the hearing, each recommendation grew new ones: remake middle schools, provide universal pre-K.
It's going to be a long process.
But most people do seem upset about one provision of the law, the requirement that teachers be highly qualified in the subject they teach.
Barnes said right now, the law only recognizes what sorts of certificates a teacher has earned.
Former Gov.
BARNES: We recommend that teachers who produce learning gains and receive a positive principal evaluation or peer review should be recognized as a highly effective teacher.
Many districts are already moving toward judging teachers by how much they improve achievement.
Teachers' unions fear this means districts will basically hold members accountable for how kids do on standardized tests.
Edward McElroy, head of the American Federation of Teachers, pointed out that the original law already required good teachers to prove their worth.
Many have fulfilled the requirements since them.
This is a credit to the people who teach in our schools.
Five years later, proposals are being put forth that we require teachers to jump through an additional hoop to prove they are worthy of teaching our nation's children.
Lawmakers could just let the law continue in its current form for another year.
Whether that should happen depends on your view of the past.
There was no one from the Department of Education to state their view that the law is improving achievement.
Senator Ted Kennedy, chair of the Senate Health and Education Committee, says that educators back home in Massachusetts tell him things are actually much worse.
The problems of poverty have become more intense than they were five years ago.
The parents are more played out than they were five years ago in being able to participate.
The school have deteriorated over the period of the five years ago.
For other lawmakers, that harsh reality may be reason to help some families escape from the public education system.

Buck McKeon, the ranking Republican on the House Education and Labor Committee, used the hearing to introduce legislation that would create scholarships, better known as vouchers, for children attending schools that are considered failing for five years.
Larry Abramson, NPR News, Washington.

Back in 1965, a few weeks before Selma drew the nation's attention to the struggle for voting rights in the South, Jimmy Lee Jackson, a 26-year-old black man, was beaten and shot to death by white state troopers during a demonstration in nearby Marion, Alabama.
His death was a catalyst for the Selma to Montgomery voting rights march.
But for decades the trooper who killed Jimmy Lee Jackson was not identified, and no charges were ever brought.
Now Attorney General Alberto Gonzales says cases like Jackson's could be re-opened as part of a federal push to investigate long, unsolved crimes of the civil rights era.

To those individuals who committed those crimes and who have lived with their guilty consciences for these many years, our message should be clear: you've not gotten away with anything; we are still on your trail.

In recent years, federal officials have already worked with state and local prosecutors to win convictions in several prominent cases, starting with the shooting death of Mississippi NAACP field secretary Medgar Evers.
Authorities also re-opened the file on Emmett Till, the black teenager who was beaten and shot after whistling at a white woman in the Mississippi Delta.
That case came to an end this past week, when a grand jury failed to return an indictment.

But for every Emmett Till and Medgar Evers, there are a dozen less well-known victims - people who were killed in what appeared to be racially-motivated crimes that in some cases were never fully investigated.
Take, for instance, Mattie Green, a domestic worker and mother of five.
In 1960, a dynamite blast ripped through her home in Ringgold, Georgia.
She was killed by falling debris.
Mattie Greene's daughter, Anna Ruth Montgomery, was 10 years old at the time.
Me and my sister was at my grandmother's house and I don't remember anything except coming up the hill and the house blown up and the clothes are all over the wires and my daddy there with my momma.
You know, I seen him holding her head in his hands.
I don't know what happened, why it happened or nothing.
The FBI and the Georgia Bureau of Investigation initially looked into the bombing, but it's not clear what the investigation concluded.
Now Mattie Greene's name is on a list of about 100 cases the FBI says it will re-examine.
It doesn't matter whether the crimes occurred 30 or 40 years ago, or yesterday.
A hate crime is a hate crime, and we're going to - if we can employ new tools, we're going to do so.
I spoke this past week with Mark Vukelich, chief of the FBI's civil rights unit.
He says agents will review the old files and look for new leads.
Then we take a look at, okay, what can we do, who can we re-interview and overcome some barriers that might exist.
Maybe somebody was scared to talk to law enforcement in the past, and how law enforcement is looked upon by this community where this crime occurred may be totally different 30 years later.
